intro: Echium dealbescens, commonly known as the white thistle or white hound's tongue, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its striking white or pale blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun, often found in coastal and inland regions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. Echium dealbescens is a perennial herb that plays a role in supporting local pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
